abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings for the project are as
            follows: the project outcome is satisfactory, the
            project's sustainability is likely, the institutional
            development impact is substantial, and the Bank and Borrower
            performance are both satisfactory. The main lessons learned
            are: The decentralized, participation-based approach to
            provision of infrastructures has proven to be successful and
            is replicable. For replication to happen, considerable
            institutional capacity in the provincial government, and
            lower level of governments are required to implement a large
            decentralized program of this type. Community development
            and empowerment is an essential prerequisite for project
            investments in local communities and became the basis for
            the new decentralization policies of the Government. It is
            clear that the project's model can support the
            devolution process, but this would need considerable effort
            to build up the capability of the weak and newly devolved
            local governments in partnership with their
            communities--with the help of other partners, service
            organizations such as the nongovernmental organizations, the
            private sector, established government, and private training
            institutions. The report contains other lessons highlighted
            from the experience of the project:  Development of adequate
            human and institutional capacity is essential at all levels
            and this was initially a problem in the project. Strong
            commitment should be ensured from the Government and
            implementation agencies in terms of minimizing the
            bureaucratic delays (speedy approval), presence of project
            staff for the project duration, and flexibility toward the
            socially oriented development. Innovative, community-based
            projects must respond flexibly and adapt to the varying
            demands generated during the community mobilization process.
            Sufficient time needs to be allowed for awareness building
            and community development before planning investments.
            Ensure that procurement capacity of the implementing agency
            is properly assessed during project preparation, take steps
            in the project design to strengthen it and that Bank
            procurement guidelines are fully understood by the Borrower.
            Ensure inclusion of a sound financial management system in
            the project design. Post implementation monitoring needs to
            be sustained which could help in resource allocation for the
            maintenance of physical and social infrastructure.
